title: Disconnect Between Rhetoric and Actions
pros: Easy hours (9:30-3:30), average benefits
cons: No communication regarding business decisions - they forced all employees to return to a hybrid schedule without providing any substantive reason for doing so. It was commonplace have department-wide zoom meetings on work from home days, then the next day when required to be in-office I would work the entire day with my headphones on and not speak to a soul, direct manager included. It was completely counterintuitive and came off as a “power play” to force people to be in the office when they didn’t want to or need to be there. It could have also been to appease shareholders showing that they were “doing their part” to prop up spiraling commercial real estate values, but we will never know because they would never explain their intentions. Lack of diverse views by leadership - this company is huge on diversity equity and inclusion. It is very important to have diverse views, backgrounds, and viewpoints, but Regency has gone overboard and in the wrong way. They act as if diversity is only skin-deep which comes off as inherently racist, intentionally giving special resume-boosting projects, the easiest portfolios to manage, and making special exceptions of employment (special ergonomic chairs, promotions in less than 12 months, and additional unapproved time off were just three examples I personally witnessed) for employees based on what they look like and how they identify rather than how they perform. Ironically, the vast majority of the leadership team and upper-level management all grew up in Jacksonville and attended UNF for college, meaning that there is in fact little to no diversity of backgrounds, education, viewpoints, or life experiences. Weak compensation - since going public, this company heavily bends the knee to their institutional investors rather than focusing on their stated values. They say their employees are their greatest asset, but give rank-and-file employees meager 3-4% annual pay raises, while rewarding the executive team with compensation raises of 50% or more each year. When I started at Regency, my compensation was $60,000 per year, and left when it had barely cracked $64,000 two years later. In contrast, the CEO’s publicly reported compensation when I started was $3.9 million per year, and the last reported compensation when I left was well over $8 million. All the benefits are getting funneled to the top. Lack of regard for workers rights - I received retaliation for discussions regarding compensation. I was finally offered a promotion after two years (I was one of only two applicants for the job, I can’t imagine why) and discussed the promotion offer with my manager. Someone overheard the conversation, reported it to the hiring manager, then the hiring manager rescinded the promotion offer due to “public and private conversations regarding compensation” according to the confirmation email after the promotion was rescinded. Exactly one week later HR served me a notice regarding my “unprofessional conduct” and told me I was not allowed to discuss my compensation except behind closed doors. They say they do what is right, but this was absolutely unacceptable and the most unprofessional business action I have witnessed in my professional career. I would not recommend working here. It’s a toxic culture

title: Review
pros: Benefits and work life balance
cons: No growth in the company

title: Could be better - Could have been worse
pros: Great PTO, 401k and profit sharing plans. Pay is okay. They do invest in their properties so you can be proud of what you're offering to the market. Good place to gain experience and take elsewhere.
cons: Not a lot of feedback from managers regarding job performance, they seem to promote based on appearances and hobnobbing instead of quality of work and experience, not a lot of openness between managers and normal employees led to feelings of us vs. them - low morale. I heard this from corporate and field offices.

title: ZERO job security
pros: Most of the employees are nice. Great benefits (if you ever get them). Nicely stocked kitchen (drinks, snacks)
cons: They just acquired another company (it is public knowledge) and it seems that things are in a state of flux at the moment. I was hired and then two months later, told my position was being eliminated. So they didn't know two months ago when they hired for the position that it was going to be eliminated? I canceled my unemployment for this job and now I'm no longer eligible to receive it. I don't know what kind of sick game they are playing, but it just isn't right to treat people this way.

title: Not all it's cracked up to be.
pros: Great place to start and move on.
cons: They claim a big emphasis on people and culture, but when it comes right down to it it's just like any other big corporation. You need to kick and scream for a promotion within, very little room for real advancement.. It was an extremely frustrating experience to be a part of a 360 review process ("high potential employee"), apply for every possible opportunity to advance my career and let down over and over again. I personally felt led on by upper management during my 3.5 year tenure and my career was stalled.

title: Great people, great company
pros: Upward mobility available Great company culture For a large REIT where things can start to become mundane, Regency is a pretty fun place to work.
cons: Any company of this size is going to have some measure of bs politics and regency is no different. You know pretty quickly you're going to have to play the "game," and if you're not willing to do that at a small measure, work somewhere else.

title: Great company
pros: Regency Centers has great benefits and excellent people to work with. When I started working for Regency Centers in 2004, Regency Centers was a great company to work for and there was a lot of upper management support from the Jacksonville office as well as direct management support from the office I worked in.
cons: After some restructuring and downsizing, I felt there was less support from upper management to the satellite offices. I only had contact with the regional officer directly above my manager about 3-4 times in the 8 years I worked there. During this time, I felt unmotivated and underutilized by direct management and had no real avenues to express my dissatisfaction.

title: Be careful - hidden issues
pros: Good benefits, some of the people are very nice
cons: The leadership engages in rampant favoritism. There’s no room to grow after a couple of years. They want you to often be in office doing busy work even if your job could easily be done from home, but they let their favorites work from home, and not others. They claim to listen to employees but when you speak out, there is punishment, unfortunately. There are a lot of old school people in leadership who are disconnected from current needs & wont listen. Boys club, if you will.

title: Best company I have worked for
pros: Great executive leadership, vision and open communication. They track and communicate progress on strategic goals every quarter. Everyone really cares about work-life balance and leaving a healthy life. I was presented with great training opportunities and learning opportunities and was always treated well. The President of the company texts me, stop by my office or calls me every year on my birthday even if it falls on a weekend.
cons: My direct supervisor could spend more time getting to know the entire team and coaching his direct reports but it isn't really a horrible situation. VP level gets what they want, no questions ask. No advancement available.

title: Accounting
pros: Decent pay, philanthropic company, semi-flex work schedule.
cons: Upper management is not what it used to be. The exec level has shifted focus from viewing employees as their most important asset to shady business practices. Hard work no longer pays off... everyone is replaceable and the loyalty isn’t reciprocated. Departments are constantly going through reorganizations. Also, don’t be fooled by a female CEO, it is a boys club and lacks diversity in all areas. Very sad because it used to be one of the best companies around. The culture has taken a major nose dive.

title: "Loved working for Regency"
pros: Excellent paid time off. Benefits and pay are decent. Great work-to-life balance. Executive Management team is AWESOME! Flexible schedules. Fun company outings and holiday party. Executive team keeps you up-to-date about the business through Town Halls.
cons: High turn-over in Real Estate Accounting Department. Some of the management team in Real Estate Accounting are impersonable and there is some favoritism. Not a lot of opportunity for advancement within the department.

title: Property Manager
pros: The emphasis on company culture and employee well-being is simply remarkable and refreshing. The vetting process HR gave was thorough, and longer than expected. But, I actually appreciated the process, as it gave me time to ensure it was a great fit both ways, and it showed they truly care who joins the team.
cons: No company is perfect, and I am sure I could list a few minor ones that every company has, but no cons worth listing.

title: Great Company and Executive Leadership
pros: Great benefits, lots of PTO and paid holidays, company outings, flex/hybrid work schedule, paid parking, and SOME really great people. Volunteering/community involvement is encouraged.
cons: Limited opportunity for advancement. Not 100% remote. Some managers and team leads are toxic and create a hostile environment.

title: Brainless corporation lucky to have so many good properties.
pros: There is a lot of paid time off, but it is sometimes detrimental because the work doesn't go away just because you do.
cons: There is very little leadership shown during these tough times. You would think someone would share their overall vision for what is expected. Individuality doesn't seem to be rewarded. Lower level employees get the exact same wage increases regardless of performance or effort.

title: Best Company I've worked for
pros: -Great company culture. They really take the time to vet people with multiple interviews before they are hired to make sure that they fit in to the culture. Lots of happy hours, lunches/dinners, teambuilding events, etc - Great Pay, Benefits, PTO, Work Life Balance - Large company so there is tons of support
cons: Not really any. You do get a lot of PTO, but it's sometimes hard to use it all because you will have a huge workload when you get back from vacation.

title: Some good aspects, some very negative
pros: Health benefits are good, paid time off is pretty good.
cons: There is unfortunately a lot of favoritism. Very little room for growth/promotion, and when available, does not seem fairly administered. A lot of closed off private discussions and mistrust in some departments. We also have to work in close and loud conditions which isn't easy at times. Company is said to be big on treating people right, but it does not translate internally, which is a shame.

title: Not too shabby
pros: The people are great to work with. Fantastic software and IT department.
cons: The salary is too low and not enough perks for it.

title: Great Company
pros: I have worked for many different companies and Regency Centers was my favorite employer. Kind, generous, great work environment and great employees. Executives knew every employee by name and genuinely cared about each employee.
cons: Working in a one of their smaller offices, there weren't as many opportunities for advancement as their larger offices, but that is not their fault.

title: An O.K. experience......
pros: Great parties and celebrations. Team members are great people. Salary is competitive.
cons: I've seen better insurance. A small company like this means everyone knows your business - even HR. People focus so much on their title and position in the company. Overall, not a very diverse company. Inexperienced and power-abusing lower-level management.

title: Amazing Leaders and Quality Culture
pros: The leaders are of great integrity and they actually care for their employees. Each person is treated with care and is recognized as an individual. Team work is encouraged and it definitely is modeled from top down. Great benefits. Culture is wonderful. One of the best places I have worked.
cons: Regional offices are intimate (which is a great PRO) but the growth in departments are minimum.

title: I am enjoying my time here.
pros: In a good economy it was a nice place to work. Would recommend for employment. Benefits package was very good.
cons: In a bad economy it was not a nice place to work. There was a lot of job cuts in the recent downturn.

title: Regency Centers is a great company to work for and a great environment to learn and grow professionally.
pros: People, Leadership, Opportunity, Family Friendly, Company is always looking for was to improve.
cons: Some processes are antiquated, minimal education assistance

title: Property Administrator
pros: Good company to start at for entry level property management position. Reasonable salary and bonus opportunities. Fair work/life balance. Good health and welfare for employees.
cons: Not much room for advancement within regional offices if you are in the property management department. You will most likely have to relocate and wait for someone to leave in order to be promoted.

title: Regency Centers provides a positive work culture that has stood the tests of the mortgage crisis.
